title: Ferguson crisis: Missouri governor says police will present 'softer front' â live | World news | The Guardian
summary: nixon calls releasing officer 's name 'important milestone '
nixon removes county police in favor of state patrol .
holder : these scenes ' can not continue '
holder : federal investigators have interviewed witnesses .
full text of obama statement on ferguson .
ferguson chief : 'we have to respond to deadly force '

text: we 're going to wrap up our live blog coverage for now , possibly to resume later tonight .
we will continue coverage of events in ferguson on our home page here .
jon swaine is in ferguson and will file a report later this evening you can follow jon on twitter @ twitterid .
here 's a summary of where things stand : protesters began to gather for a fifth night thursday evening in ferguson to demand answers in the 9 august police killing of 18-year-old michael brown .
police have yet to name the officer involved or to release an incident report .
police said they would use a new plan of operation in the streets thursday night , designed to deescalate confrontations with protesters and encourage dialogue .
missouri governor jay nixon announced the state patrol would be taking the lead in the police effort , replacing the st louis county police department .
the officer leading tonight 's patrol , capt .
ron johnson , said he would be out talking to protesters : when we talk about boots on the ground , my boots are going to be on the ground .
the changes followed a night of clashes wednesday in which police used rubber bullets and tear gas on peaceful protesters .
at least 10 people were arrested wednesday .
president barack obama took a break from his vacation to address the situation thursday afternoon .
he called on all sides to take a step back and think about how we 're going to be moving forward .
there is never an excuse for violence against police , said obama .
there 's also no excuse for police to use excessive force against peaceful protests .
attorney general eric holder said federal investigators had interviewed eyewitnesses to the killing of michael brown and that a full account of what happened would emerge .
the county is conducting a separate probe .
saint louis county executive charlie dooley asked people to calm down .
this ought not to be a black and white thing , he said .
we can do better than this .
a of the governor and capt .
johnson 's news conference , via kmov in st louis : russell kinsaul ( @ russellkinsaul ) capt .
ron johnson of the missouri highway patrol will now be in charge of crowd control in ferguson .
# kmov
the guardian 's jon swaine is in ferguson .
he reports that capt .

johnson of the state patrol asked his officers to forgo teargas masks : jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) ron johnson , in charge of policing ferguson tonight : `` before i came here i had all my officers take their teargas masks off their belt '' jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) mo state highway patrol captain ron johnson says tonight police intend to keep open w florissant , which has been blocked/site of clashes
softer front ?
conetta ( @ bmoreconetta ) police assembling at staging area near # ferguson now

in a piece for comment is free , roxane gay writes that ferguson is an occupation happening in plain sight and a display of police power run amok : ferguson is the site of an occupation happening in plain sight , and the police remain undeterred because they can occupy , because they know they have unlimited power , because they know they can not be stopped .
i am stunned but i should not be .
i recognize the luxury of my disbelief .
i will never allow myself such luxury again .
today , i truly understand privilege .

i am outraged but i do not know what to do with my outrage that might be productive , that might move this world forward toward a place where black lives matter , and where black parents no longer need to have the talk with their children about how not to be killed by police and where anger over a lifetime of wrongs is not judged , but understood and supported .
read the full piece here .
the guardian jessica glenza ( @ jessicaglenza ) has spoken with missouri rep emanuel cleaver ii about the events in ferguson .
cleaver 's district is across the state in kansas city , where he used to be mayor .
something is wrong in ferguson , and it did n't just start with the killing of michael brown , cleaver said .
it took that killing to bring the light of inadequacy on that community 's leadership .

jessica reports : asked whether he thought that statements issued by us leaders , including president obama and senator claire mccaskill , were helpful in defusing the situation , cleaver said , the president did the right thing , but understand the two things that are still hanging out there that must be dealt with , first of all until the police department or the city prosecutor makes a statement there is going to be this intense sus which creates anger .
as for armored vehicles and other military-style equipment appearing on ferguson streets , cleaver said , we need to reevaluate distributing this kind of equipment to municipalities .
and if we 're going to do it we at least must have other requirements , including something as simple as training .
just think about it the same equipment we 've used to fight in iraq we put on the streets of ferguson , missouri , cleaver said .
that 's shameful .

the guardian 's jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) , who attended the news conference with governor jay nixon , flags a key line : promising a softer front , nixon said : attitudes were n't improving , and the blocks toward expression appeared to be a flashpoint .
capt johnson is asked what he will do differently tonight .
will he used armor vehicles and body armor ?
we 're going to go back and assess today , he says .
when we talk about boots on the ground , my boots are going to be on the ground .
he says he 'll go to the quiktrip that burned down and meet with people there himself .
he says they wo n't take resources out there that we do n't need .
he says they want to hear people speak not just let them speak but listening .
a destroyed quiktrip store is in the background as demonstrators hold signs while protesting the death of black teenager michael brown in ferguson , missouri august 12 , 2014 .
anzuoni/reuters
nixon is asked about his relationship with the black community .
he replies : i appreciate the relationship i have with so many friends over so many years in this community i tremendously appreciate that .
i 'm going to continue to not use this as a time to divide or to see how loud i can talk .
people have first amendment rights , i 've got executive challenges here .
he says there should be room for people to publicly disagree .
he 's asked about criticism on twitter and one specific criticism apparently involving a four-letter word .
he replies : i try to put gasoline into the engine of fire engines when i see them .
not on the fires .
i feel that is more productive .
nixon says the justice department and st louis county investigations are hustling ahead .
i think we let them do their jobs .
i know they 're hustling their tails off .
nixon is asked how he wants to heal the deeper wound he referred to .
we 're focused on operational things , he says .
we 'd like to see the danger level go down on a lot of fronts .
we 'd like to see the investigations that are out there get completed .
it 's really important for people to know what happened and how it happened .
nixon is asked about the problem of persistent racial profiling of black residents of the st louis area , including traffic stops and other reported harrassment .
nixon replies that the situation touches a deeper nerve : this feels a little like an old wound that has been hit again .
and so the pain you feel it feels like a little bit of a longtime simmering .
and that i think is natural for all of us to see and to watch .
the key to this is to get control , let voices be heard , make sure we protect property showing less force on the front side , but ultimately getting to some of these deeper problems .
these are deep and existing problems not only in missouri but in america it touches a deeper nerve .
i think ultimately we will be graded or gauged as to whether or not this was an opportunity used to be able to make some longer term understanding
nixon is asked whether he will look into the arrest and jailing of peaceful protesters wednesday .
there 's been gunfire let 's not kid ourselves folks , this has been a difficult zone .
i think tonight you 'll see an attempt to move forward people and to move back a little bit of equipment .
the challenge we face today is not whether we have enough officers or have shown enough strength on the police side , nixon says .
we 've shown that .
but he says business owners and others would be protected from illegal acts .

documents.title: nixon calls releasing officer 's name 'important milestone '
text: nixon says he does n't know the name of the officer who killed michael brown .
i would hold that the appropriate release of that name would be done as expeditiously as possible as long as there 's appropriate security , he says .
i think it would be an important milestone to get that out as expeditiously as possible .
nixon is asked who was in charge of the heavy-handed police presence wednesday , armor , assault rifles , camo and all .
that was yesterday .
tonight is tonight .
tomorrow is tomorrow .
our hope is that this operation shift will begin the process of lowering the intensity of those direct interactions and potential risks while at the same time allowing people to speak .
the reporter persists : who was in charge ?
i 'm not looking backwards , nixon says .
i 'm looking forward .
nixon : all of us have seen some level of escalation in terms of the arms that were used as well as some of the conduct .
he calls for a dimming of that escalation .

he says clearly you 'll see as the afternoon-evening starts , a different clearly , the strong force on the front line , our hopes would be that we have the ability to get a little more peaceful interaction on the front .
nixon : i think we all have been concerned about the vision that the world has seen about this region .

and i think we 're all about making sure that we allow peaceful protests , that we use force only when necessary , that we step back a little bit and allow some of the energy to be felt in this region appropriately i think you 're going to see i think that while maintaining the peace , but allowing more movement , trying to bring in a different how should we say a different tone of the amplitude of the protective force , my sense is that people on the ground are working on some of those changes anyway .
slay thanks st louis county pd officers and others in the streets .
i want to thank you for your service .
thank you for respecting the badge , for honoring your oath .
st louis mayor francis slay speaks .
he says michael brown 's family , friends , and this community are all in mourning .
slay calls for a full , fair and transparent investigation and for justice to be served .
he says the leaders are in common agreement : justice must happen , the grieving must be comforted , the angry must be heard and the innocent must be protected .
saint louis county executive charlie dooley says he 's for justice , not revenge .
he said the community needs to calm down , stand down and let 's be reasonable .
let 's have a conversation .
how do we perceive ourselves ?
how does the world look at us as a coomunity ?
this ought not to be a black and white thing we can do better than this .
capt johnson is speaking .
i appreciate the significance of this responsibility , he says .
i grew up here , and this is currently my community and my home .
he says it 's a priority to build trust and maintain communication with residents .
i understand the anger and fear that the citizens of ferguson are feeling , and our police officers will respect both of those , he says .

documents.title: nixon removes county police in favor of state patrol
text: missouri highway patrol under ron johnson , who grew up in this area , will direct the law enforcement team , nixon says .
the st louis county police department is apparently out of the leadership .
nixon is speaking .
he thanks the university of missouri st louis which is hosting the conference .
he says he was briefed this morning and spoke with the president .
he says he has met with faith and civic leaders and visited the scene .
he says he appreciated the opportunity to speak with members of the neighborhood , who said they want peace .
my message to the people of ferguson is that these voices have been heard .
what 's been going on here the last few days is not what missouri 's about but lately it 's been more like a war zone .
nbc news has a camera on the nixon news conference , yet to begin :
the missouri governor is due to speak soon .
jonathan shorman ( @ jshormannl ) many national reporters are about to have their first jay nixon press conference experience .
st. louis county and dellwood police detain two people , 13 aug 2014 .
both people were released after being questioned .
/rex
via st. louis public radio : maria altman ( @ radioaltman ) # ferguson this afternoon .
protesters say they wo n't go home until the officer who killed michael brown is locked up .

documents.title: callout for reader stories
text: [ reposted from this morning ] the st louis post-dispatch editorial page and the the guardian us opinion page have launched a joint project to collect readers ' stories about the relationship in their communities between residents and law enforcement .
contribute to this story by clicking here .
what is your police racial profiling story ?
how did it change you ?
if you 're from ferguson or the st louis region , tell the world the real story , from on the ground , that you think needs to be told and what needs to change .
your submissions could be used for special post-dispatch / guardian interactive features as the story unfolds .
the st louis riverfront times has published a list of 7 peaceful ways to respond to michael brown 's death , ferguson unrest .
here 's no.4 : 4 .
sign the petition for the michael brown law .
more than 1,000 people have already signed a petition demanding that police officers to wear cameras at all times .
police in columbia have been wearing body cameras since last month .
update : here 's a similar petition with 116,000+ signatures : please enact new federal laws to protect citizens from police violence and misconduct .
read the full list here .

a democratic congressman plans to introduce a bill to restrict a defense department program that provides machine guns and other surplus military equipment for free to local law enforcement agencies across the us , the ap reports : rep. hank johnson said the legislation is in response to the death of an unarmed teenager who was shot by a police officer in a st. louis suburb .
johnson said city streets should be a place for businesses and families , not tanks and m16s .
he said a pentagon program that transfers surplus military equipment to state and local law enforcement has led to police agencies resembling paramilitary forces .
militarizing america 's main streets wo n't make us any safer , just more fearful and more reticent , johnson said .
he said his bill would limit the type of military equipment that can be transferred to law enforcement , and require states to certify they can account for all equipment received .

documents.title: holder : federal investigators have interviewed witnesses
text: federal investigators have already conducted interviews with eyewitnesses on the scene at the time of the shooting incident on saturday , attorney general holder said at the end of his statement thursday .
those investigators come from the civil rights division of the department of justice and the u.s. attorney 's office in missouri .
our review will take time to conduct , but it will be thorough and fair , holder said .
a defense department spokesman said a program to give secondhand military gear to local law enforcement was useful and prevented waste .

here are remarks by rear adm. john kirby , the pentagon press secretary , via guardian national security editor spencer ackerman ( @ attackerman ) : there is a law enforcement support program that the defense department administers which provides to law enforcement agencies around the country surplus military equipment , gear , arms , ammunition , vehicles .
this is a useful program that allows for the re-use of military equipment that otherwise would be disposed of that can be used again by law enforcement agencies to serve their citizens .
the program serves a purpose .
that said , it is up to law enforcement agencies to speak to how and what they gain through this system , and i 'm not going to inject the pentagon into this discussion .
how this equipment is used to serve local citizens is up for local law enforcement agencies to speak to .

documents.title: holder : these scenes ' can not continue '
text: attorney general eric holder released a statement thursday following his meeting with president obama to discuss the latest developments in ferguson : this morning , i met with president obama to discuss the events in ferguson , missouri .
like the president , i extend my heartfelt condolences to the family of michael brown .
while his death has understandably caused heartache within the community , it is clear that the scenes playing out in the streets of ferguson over the last several nights can not continue .
for one thing , while the vast majority of protests have been peaceful , acts of violence by members of the public can not be condoned .
looting and willful efforts to antagonize law enforcement officers who are genuinely trying to protect the public do nothing to remember the young man who has died .
such conduct is unacceptable and must be unequivocally condemned .
by the same token , the law enforcement response to these demonstrations must seek to reduce tensions , not heighten them .
those who peacefully gather to express sympathy for the family of michael brown must have their rights respected at all times .
and journalists must not be harassed or prevented from covering a story that needs to be told .

at a time when we must seek to rebuild trust between law enforcement and the local community , i am deeply concerned that the deployment of military equipment and vehicles sends a conflicting message .
at my direction , department officials have conveyed these concerns to local authorities .

also at my direction , the department is offering through our cops office and office of justice programs technical assistance to local authorities in order to help conduct crowd control and maintain public safety without relying on unnecessarily extreme displays of force .
the local authorities in missouri have accepted this offer of assistance as of this afternoon .
this july 14 , 2014 file photo shows attorney general eric holder speaking at the justice department in washington .

martinez monsivais/ap department officials from the community relations service are also on the ground in missouri to help convene law enforcement officials and civic and faith leaders to plot out steps to reduce tensions in the community .
the latest such meeting was convened in ferguson as recently as this morning .
over time , these conversations should consider the role that increased diversity in law enforcement can play in helping to build trust within communities .
all the while , the federal civil rights investigation into the shooting incident itself continues , in parallel with the local investigation into state law violations .

our investigators from the civil rights division and u.s. attorney 's office in missouri have already conducted interviews with eyewitnesses on the scene at the time of the shooting incident on saturday .
our review will take time to conduct , but it will be thorough and fair .
as our live blog coverage continues , here 's a summary of where things stand : missouri governor jay nixon said there would be a change in the tone of law enforcement in ferguson .
we 're working through a number of operational things to make some shifts , he said .
nixon was expected to give details at a news conference at 3pm central / 4pm eastern .

the use of rubber bullets , tear gas and military-grade armor and weaponry wednesday night against demonstrators protesting the police killing last saturday of 18-year-old michael brown drew national outrage .
americans have been deeply disturbed by the images we 've seen , president barack obama said in a statement on the crackdown .
obama said there was no excuse for police to use excessive force against peaceful protests .
he also said there is never an excuse for violence against police .
political leaders asked a community demanding answers about the killing of brown to wait until a county attorney 's investigation was complete .
the facts will become known , all of them , senator claire mccaskill said .
obama said he had tasked the justice department and the fbi to investigate the death of michael brown and that he was personally receiving updates .
read the previous summary here .

missouri governor jay nixon speaks about the unrest in the town of ferguson following the shooting death of michael brown to residents and faith and community leaders during a forum held at christ the king ucc church on august 14 , 2014 in florissant , missouri .
olson/getty images

documents.title: full text of obama statement on ferguson
text: here is president barack obama 's statement on ferguson in full , via the white house press shop : now , second , i want to address something that 's been in the news over the last couple of days and that 's the situation in ferguson , missouri .
i know that many americans have been deeply disturbed by the images we 've seen in the heartland of our country , as police have clashed with people protesting .
today , i 'd like us all to take a step back and think about how we 're going to be moving forward .
this morning , i received a thorough update on the situation from attorney general eric holder , who has been following it and been in communication with his team .
i 've already tasked the department of justice and the fbi to independently investigate the death of michael brown , along with local officials on the ground .

the department of justice is also consulting with local authorities about ways that they can maintain public safety without restricting the right of peaceful protest and while avoiding unnecessary escalation .
i made clear to the attorney general that we should do what is necessary to help determine exactly what happened , and to see that justice is done .
i also just spoke with governor jay nixon of missouri .

i expressed my concern over the violent turn that events have taken on the ground , and underscored that now is the time for all of us to reflect on what 's happened , and to find a way to come together going forward .
he is going to be traveling to ferguson .

he is a good man and a fine governor , and i 'm confident that , working together , he is going to be able to communicate his desire to make sure that justice is done and his desire to make sure that public safety is maintained in an appropriate way .
of course , it 's important to remember how this started .
we lost a young man , michael brown , in heartbreaking and tragic circumstances .
he was 18 years old .
his family will never hold michael in their arms again .

and when something like this happens , the local authorities - including the police - have a responsibility to be open and transparent about how they are investigating that death , and how they are protecting the people in their communities .
there is never an excuse for violence against police , or for those who would use this tragedy as a cover for vandalism or looting .
there 's also no excuse for police to use excessive force against peaceful protests , or to throw protestors in jail for lawfully exercising their first amendment rights .

and here , in the united states of america , police should not be bullying or arresting journalists who are just trying to do their jobs and report to the american people on what they see on the ground .
put simply , we all need to hold ourselves to a high standard , particularly those of us in positions of authority .
i know that emotions are raw right now in ferguson and there are certainly passionate differences about what has happened .
there are going to be different accounts of how this tragedy occurred .
there are going to be differences in terms of what needs to happen going forward .
that 's part of our democracy .
but let 's remember that we 're all part of one american family .

we are united in common values , and that includes belief in equality under the law ; a basic respect for public order and the right to peaceful public protest ; a reverence for the dignity of every single man , woman and child among us ; and the need for accountability when it comes to our government .
so now is the time for healing .
now is the time for peace and calm on the streets of ferguson .
now is the time for an open and transparent process to see that justice is done .
and i 've asked that the attorney general and the u.s. attorney on the scene continue to work with local officials to move that process forward .
they will be reporting to me in the coming days about what 's being done to make sure that happens .
an anchor at local ksdk news tweets a of a rally today outside the ferguson police department : ryan dean ( @ ryandeanksdk ) protest outside the # feguson police department .
seems to be a different approach by police .
no armored units
missouri senator claire mccaskill , a democrat , is speaking to reporters .
she says it 's appropriate not to release information about the investigation into the killing of michael brown until the probe is complete .
the information will become public .
the facts will become known , all of them .
i 'm not going to second-guess law enforcement about information they are giving out .
because i know they are [ aiming ] to make sure they find the truth .

reporting from ferguson , the guardian 's jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) has spoken again with st louis county police spokesman brian schellman about criticism that the law enforcement response has been heavy handed .
luckily for both sides , there 's been no lethal force used , schellman tells jon : but what has been used is things like molotov cocktails .
those are deadly weapons .
so the police response to the molotov cocktails was less lethal munitions .
we 're not using deadly force when a deadly force molotov cocktail was used on us .
schellman could not confirm that any molotov cocktails or bottles had actually struck any officers .
but does that make it ok for people to throw ?
i do n't know , he said .
to me it does n't .
it does n't make it ok. to say it does n't really matter because they did n't hurt any of the officers ' , we ca n't think like that .
so , do we have to wait until one of our officers gets hurt ?
that 's the big question here .
asked if he meant that the answer was no , schellman said : absolutely .
speaking late on wednesday night at the police command centre , schellman said officers had used as much restraint as we could given the situation .

the military force brought to bear by the police in ferguson is a stark illustration of the militarization of police forces in the us , write the guardian 's jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) in ferguson and amanda holpuch ( @ holpuch ) in new york : i 'm a soldier , i 'm a military officer and i know when there 's a need for such thing , but i do n't think in a small town of 22,000 people you need up-armor vehicles , cristian balan , a communications officer in the us army , who was not speaking on behalf of the us military , told the guardian .
even if there 's an active shooter are you really going to use an up-armor vehicle ?
do you really need it ?
in the eyes of the government , the answer increasingly seems to be a resounding yes .

a senior counsel with the aclu tells the guardian that the militarization of police contributes to violence instead of detracting from it : as we 've seen in ferguson , the militarization of policing tends to escalate the risk of violence to the communities , said kara dansky , senior counsel with the aclu 's center for justice and the prime author of its june 2014 report on the militarization of us police .

we think that historically , the police and the military have had different roles and that american neighborhoods are n't war zones and police officers should not be treating us like wartime enemies .
read the full piece here .
senator rand paul calls in time magazine for the de-militarization of us police forces .
there is a systemic problem with today 's law enforcement , he writes : not surprisingly , big government has been at the heart of the problem .

washington has incentivized the militarization of local police precincts by using federal dollars to help municipal governments build what are essentially small armieswhere police departments compete to acquire military gear that goes far beyond what most of americans think of as law enforcement .

[ ] when you couple this militarization of law enforcement with an erosion of civil liberties and due process that allows the police to become judge and jurynational security letters , no-knock searches , broad general warrants , pre-conviction forfeiturewe begin to have a very serious problem on our hands .
read the full piece here .

update : dylan scott in talking points memo reports the ferguson police received military gear direct from the pentagon through what 's known as the 1033 program , a federal program that the aclu says has been a key catalyst to the broader escalation of law enforcement force in the united states : the 1033 program , which was approved by congress in 1992 to help law enforcement fight the war on drugs and was expanded in 1997 , allows police departments to request and receive refurbished military equipment from the u.s. defense department free of charge .
read the full piece here .
jackson is answering questions about why law enforcement has not released the identity of the officer who killed brown .
he brings up possible charges in the case , saying county attorney mccullough 's policy is not to release somebody 's name until they are formally charged .
jackson says county prosecutor robert mccullough will continue to gather evidence in the killing of michael brown to be presented to a grand jury when it 's ready .
he mentions toxicology reports .
it will take some time , jackson says .
if individuals are in a crowd that 's attacking police , they need to get out of that crowd , jackson says .
he says police can not individually quiz protesters as to whether they are violent .
he says the media 's not a target .

documents.title: ferguson chief : 'we have to respond to deadly force '
text: ferguson police chief thomas jackson is holding a news conference .
he says that police will attempt to facilitate the protests tonight , and he wants the protesters to realize that the law enforcement goal is facilitation .
we 're going to have cones , things like that .
we 're not going to have barricades we 're asking for cooperation , he says .
jackson is asked if armored vehicles will be used .
the tactical units will be out there .
if [ there are ] firebombs , property getting destroyed we have to respond to deadly force .

huffington post journalist ryan reilly , who was detained by police in ferguson wednesday with washington post journalist wesley lowery , has posted to youtube video that he shot after the two were released .
in the video the journalists ask police for information about their arrest which is roundly denied .

police told them there was no report in their arrest and that they , the police , could not help the journalists get the names of the arresting officer or any other official account of why they were taken into custody .
obama says it 's important not to forget how the events in ferguson began we lost a young man , michael brown , in heartbreaking and tragic circumstances .
he was 18 years old and his family will never hold michael in their arms again .
local authorities have a responsibility to be open and transparent , he says .
there is never an excuse for violence against police or looting , obama says .
but , he says , there is also no excuse for police to use excessive force against peaceful protests or to throw protesters in jail for exercising their first amendment rights .
and here in the united states of american police should not be bullying or arresting journalists who are just trying to do their jobs i know that emotions are raw right now in ferguson .
and there are certainly passionate differences about what is happening .
there are different accounts .
obama says he expects further reports in the coming days from law enforcement at the scene .
he exits without taking questions .
president barack obama speaks about the situations in iraq and in ferguson , mo. , thursday , aug. 14 , 2014 , in edgartown , mass. , during his family vacation on the island of martha 's vineyard .
( ap photo/jacquelyn martin ) martin/ap
obama : i know that many americans have been deeply disturbed by the images we 've seen .
he says i 'd like us all to take a step back to figure out how we 'll move forward .
he says he 's tasked the justice department and the fbi to investigate the death of michael brown .
he says he spoke with nixon and underscored his concern about the violent turn of events on the ground .
obama begins speaking .
he says he 's been monitoring two issues closely : iraq and ferguson .
he begins with a discussion of the evacuation of members of the yazidi religious minority from mt sinjar in northern iraq .
nixon apologizes for being late , but he was on the phone with the president .
[ obama ] said to me a number of things , not the least of which is to send he and the first lady 's wishes of peace and justice to this community , nixon says .
nixon says obama promised his assistance in any way he could do it .
he wanted me specifically to thank the faith leaders and other leaders who are leading with vigor but with peace .
nixon says his next announcement will be at 3p central time .
polling analyst harry enten , now of fivethirtyeight , formerly of the guardian : harry enten ( @ forecasterenten ) btw , jay nixon lost white voters 51 % -46 % in 2012 .
only won because he won african-americans 92 % -6 % .
nixon continues : we 're working through a number of operational things to make some shifts , where i think you all will see a different tone .
nixon says the shift will be made so that the tone and that the proper energy and healing takes place .
we just ca n't have lawlesssness .
we 've got to use that energy as an excuse to pushe

documents.title: nixon : 'we are going to be making some shifts '
text: missouri governor jay nixon is speaking in ferguson at a church .

he refers to changes to be made in the law enforcement response to the protests : we are over the next few hours going to be making some shifts so that people are feeling safe as long as they are respecting the property of their neighbors and the vast , vast , vast majority have done just that .
john lewis , the civil rights leader and longtime congressman from georgia , has decried the harsh police response in ferguson .
people must respect the citizens , lewis said .
you do not refer to citizens as animals .
you do not dress like you 're ready to be engaged in warfare .

lewis also is quoted as having called for martial law , which is hard to square with his record of civil disobedience and leadership of the student nonviolent coordinating committee at the height of the civil rights movement .
chris geidner ( @ chrisgeidner ) um .
rt @ twitterid : rep. john lewis , on @ twitterid , just called for president obama to declare martial law in ferguson .
that was unexpected .
update : here 's the text of lewis ' statement via buzzfeed : andrew kaczynski ( @ buzzfeedandrew ) civil rights icon john lewis had some powerful comments on ferguson :

here 's a selection of recently published material from comment is free , the guardian 's opinion page : ferguson is not a war zone we need to talk about more than just mike brown : the tragic events here in missouri could be the beginning of something .
but we need to build a path toward reconciliation by pamela merritt ferguson is what happens when white suburban cops get weapons of war michael brown 's shooting was one thing .
the protests are another .
but military might does not belong on main street by sadhbh walshe the ghost of mike brown why must a dead black child defend his right to life ?
: the assumption that black people must be guilty of something lies behind the ferguson shooting , and the police reaction by steven w thrasher
the presidential motorcade is on the move , according to white house pool reports .

as we wait for president barack obama to speak about ferguson you can catch that live on the white house web site here here 's a summary of where things stand : the morning after a brutal police crackdown on demonstrators protesting the police killing of michael brown , 18 , in ferguson , missouri , political leaders called for restraint .
we need to de-militarize this situation , multiple leaders said .
president barack obama was scheduled to address the crackdown any minute and missouri governor jay nixon was scheduled to hold a news conference later thursday .
police used rubber bullets , tear gas , noisemakers , flashbangs , armored vehicles and other intimidation to drive largely peaceful protests off the streets of ferguson wednesday night .
at least 10 people were arrested , police said .
up to 40 law enforcement jurisdictions were involved in the ferguson response , a st louis paper said .
there was speculation that the missouri governor would announce a change in leadership in the law enforcement response .
the aclu has filed a petition for the police department to release its incident report in the 9 august killing of brown , who was unarmed .
the official account of st louis mayor francis slay is tweeting about ferguson .
because st louis does not incorporate the many communities around it , its official population is relatively small , at 315,000 .
but ferguson is part of the larger st louis metropolitan area , with about 3m total residents .
i question many of the tactics used in ferguson , slay writes , especially the arrest of journalists .
mayorslay.com ( @ mayorslay ) i think it is imperative to distinguish between protest and violence .
only the latter warrants arrest .
# fgs he continues : i have spoken to federal , mo , county officials , expressed these views and offered the city 's experience .
it is my strongest hope that subsequent events do not delay or obscure swift justice in the michael brown case .
in the earliest days , the influential voices belonged to michael brown 's parents .
let them be heeded again .
the first thing that should happen is to demilitarize the situation in ferguson .

documents.title: aclu sues for police records in brown killing
text: the ferguson police so far have declined to supply the incident report on the 9 august killing of michael brown or to name the officer who pulled the trigger .
the aclu has now filed a lawsuit seeking police records under the missouri sunshine law , cbs news reports .
a copy of the petition has been posted to scrib 'd .
by law the police department has three business days to reply .
the senior senator from missouri is on the scene .
matt pearce ( @ mattdpearce ) sen. mccaskill says she 's been working on `` demilitarizing the police response , '' draws standing ovation at church .
update : here 's her full statement : mike memoli ( @ mikememoli ) full @ twitterid stmt
ferguson police chief thomas jackson will hold two news conferences thursday , one just after noon central time and the second around 6 p.m. , local station ksdk reports .
the st louis county police chief is jon belmar .
( h/t : @ twitterid )
a protester throws back a smoke bomb while clashing with police in ferguson , missouri august 13 , 2014 .
anzuoni/reuters riot police clear demonstrators from a street in ferguson , missouri , august 13 , 2014 .
anzuoni/reuters jeremiah parker , 4 , stands in front of his mother , shatara parker , as they attend a protest wednesday , aug. 13 , 2014 , in ferguson , mo .
roberson/ap
the white house says the president 's statement today will address ferguson and iraq .
eric schultz ( @ schultz44 ) today at 12:15 , the president will give an update on the latest developments in iraq , and a statement on the situation in ferguson .
( h/t : @ twitterid )
the city of st. louis spoke directly to the white house last night about the situation in ferguson , jessica lussenhop of the st louis riverfront times reports .
lussenhop quotes a spokesman for rep. william macy clay as saying that missouri governor jay nixon plans to make an announcement about the law enforcement response in ferguson .
as many as 40 different law enforcement jurisdictions have sent officers to assist in ferguson , lussenhop says : the county assumed command of the investigation and of ground operations .

over the last several days as many as 40 other jurisdictions have sent officers to assist ferguson and county police , including the city of st. louis , the state police , the missouri highway patrol and a host of other small municipalities .
read the full report here .
missouri governor jay nixon is scheduled to hold a news conference at 2.30pm central time , it appears .
that would follow the president 's statement by a couple hours .

late wednesday , nixon released a statement on the situation , in which he urge [ d ] law enforcement agencies to keep the peace and respect the rights of residents and the press : the worsening situation in ferguson is deeply troubling , and does not represent who we are as missourians or as americans .

while we all respect the solemn responsibility of our law enforcement officers to protect the public , we must also safeguard the rights of missourians to peaceably assemble and the rights of the press to report on matters of public concern .
i have been closely monitoring the situation and will continue to be in communication with local leaders , and i will be in north st. louis county tomorrow .
as governor , i am committed to ensuring the pain of last weekend 's tragedy does not continue to be compounded by this ongoing crisis .

once again , i ask that members of the community demonstrate patience and calm while the investigation continues , and i urge law enforcement agencies to keep the peace and respect the rights of residents and the press during this difficult time .
the rough handling by police of ferguson residents has also been applied to reporters at the scene .
washington post reporter wesley lowery has described his arrest along with huffington post reporter ryan reilly as the two sat working inside a mcdonalds .
police have repeatedly objected to news crews and residents filming them .
later on wednesday , an al-jazeera america crew filming a police position from a distance was hit with a tear gas canister fired to land at the base of their tripods .
the gas quickly engulfs the crew , which flees .
here is video of the attack on the al-jazeera crew .
the police later appeared to confiscate the crew 's equipment : daveweigel ( @ daveweigel ) it 's early , but this is the tweet of the day .
rt @ twitterid : looters stealing camera equipment in ferguson :
the guardian 's jon swaine is in ferguson , where on monday he documented the use of wooden slugs by law enforcement on protesters .
st louis county police deny firing them .
jon says he has n't heard of further occurrences .
jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) have n't seen or heard of any wooden baton rounds , as used on mon , being shot last night .
and county cops stress it was n't them who shot them

president barack obama , currently on vacation on the island of martha 's vineyard in massachusetts , received a briefing last night after midnight from us attorney general eric holder on the events in ferguson .
the white house has just announced that the president will interrupt his vacation again today at 12.15 et to deliver a statement .
the topic of the statement is unspecified update : iraq and ferguson .

video ( from wednesday ) : ferguson residents react to michael brown shooting after teenager michael brown was shot dead by police in missouri , the guardian 's jon swaine met with shocked residents .
officers are supposed to protect and serve , ' said brittany troupe , 24 .
i do n't understand why this happened . '
the shooting prompted riots in ferguson at the weekend , while on monday police fired rubber bullets and used teargas on protesters .
the mayor of ferguson declines to join the hail of criticism directed at the county police department .
michael calderone ( @ mlcalderone ) on msnbc , ferguson mayor james knowles defending police conduct : i ca n't second guess these officers

documents.title: callout for reader stories
text: the st louis post-dispatch editorial page and the the guardian us opinion page have launched a joint project to collect readers ' stories about the relationship in their communities between residents and law enforcement .
contribute to this story by clicking here .
what is your police racial profiling story ?
how did it change you ?
if you 're from ferguson or the st louis region , tell the world the real story , from on the ground , that you think needs to be told and what needs to change .
your submissions could be used for special post-dispatch / guardian interactive features as the story unfolds .
there has been speculation that missouri governor jay nixon plans to order the st louis county police department , currently heading up the response in ferguson , to stand down .
bloomberg reporter derek wallbank spoke to missouri representative william lacy clay : derek wallbank ( @ dwallbank ) clay : `` the gov .

just called me and he 's on his way to st. louis now to announce he 's taking st. louis county police out of the situation '' the guardian has just spoken with steven engelhardt , the communications director for clay .
he declined to confirm the report , calling it premature .
joelcurrier ( @ joelcurrier ) st. louis co police say they are not aware of reports that they are being relieved of duty in # ferguson probe .
# mikebrown
the guardian 's jon swaine is in ferguson .
jon swaine ( @ jonswaine ) .
@ tobyharnden found a spent ( and potentially fatal ) bean-bag round fired by police last night

good morning and welcome to our liveblog coverage of a police crackdown in ferguson , missouri , in the aftermath of the police killing last saturday of an unarmed black teenager , 18-year-old michael brown .

the police response to demonstrators protesting against brown 's death escalated sharply late wednesday , with police using tear gas , rubber bullets , flashbang devices , noisemakers and armored vehicles to scatter unarmed crowds .
at least 10 people were arrested wednesday night , police said .
the guardian 's jon swaine has been in ferguson since monday .

early on thursday he described the latest violence : dozens of officers , some carrying assault rifles , advanced with a pair of armoured trucks on the young and predominantly african american crowd , after two glass bottles were thrown at their lines from a largely peaceful protest against the shooting of michael brown by a city policeman .

demonstrators , who for hours had sniper rifles trained on them while they protested with their hands up as an emblem of peaceful protest , complained that they were subjected to military-style tactics as they fled through gas-filled residential side-streets .
residents and outside observers have condemned the police tactics as needlessly heavy-handed .
the rising chorus of protest finally drew a response from missouri governor jay nixon on wednesday just before midnight , when he said he would skip the state fair thursday to visit the scene .
nixon had been criticized for remaining all but silent on the issue .

the white house said early on thursday that barack obama had interrupted his vacation on martha 's vineyard , massachusetts , to be briefed by the us attorney general , eric holder , on the situation .
on wednesday , swaine witnessed the arrest of two reporters who had been sitting at work inside a mcdonalds , including one from the washington post .
marty baron , the post 's editor , condemned the arrest as an assault on the freedom of the press to cover the news .
ferguson , a city of 21,000 , is attached to st louis , which has a metropolitan area of almost 3m residents .
st louis county police are leading the law enforcement response .
brian schellman , a spokesman for the county police , told the guardian at the law enforcement command centre late on wednesday that chiefs would review tactics after the night 's events .
we 'll be running the live blog throughout the day to follow the latest events in ferguson , and the reaction to them .
